project_metadata.paper_title: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Cooperative Deployment of a Generalized, Archaeology-Specific Field Data Collection System
project_metadata.journal: In Mobilizing the Past for a Digital Future: The Potential of Digital Archaeology, edited by Erin Walcek Averett, Jody Michael Gordon, and Derek B. Counts, 337-371. Grand Forks, ND: The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota
project_metadata.research_context: This paper documents the cooperative deployment of the FAIMS (Federated Archaeological Information Management Systems) mobile platform through three archaeological field projects in Turkey, Malawi, and Peru. It explores co-development between archaeologists and software developers for generalised field data collection systems.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS project received initial NeCTAR funding of AUD $949,500 in 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS mobile platform entered public beta release in November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: which entered public beta release in November 2013

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS received ARC LIEF award of AUD $945,000 total in 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2014, the FAIMS project received an Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF) award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS 2.0 released in November 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

evidence.evidence_text: Fees account for 5% of FAIMS budget, infrastructure grants 95%
evidence.verbatim_quote: To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%

evidence.evidence_text: In-kind contributions at Macquarie University alone total approximately $100,000 per year
evidence.verbatim_quote: which, for example, total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone

evidence.evidence_text: Two doctoral students successfully customised and deployed their own FAIMS systems
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two small projects, both undertaken by doctoral students, have successfully customised and deployed their own systems

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: 19 workflows created for 17 projects, 11 supported in field since November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Pre-configured local server costs AUD $1,700–$3,500 from vendors
evidence.verbatim_quote: Purchasing a pre-configured local server with all necessary hardware costs AUD $1,700–$3,500 from one of these vendors (excluding tablets)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Online or local server lease costs approximately AUD $150–$200 per month
evidence.verbatim_quote: Alternatively, an online or local server can be leased for approximately AUD $150–$200 per month

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Module customisation costs AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season
evidence.verbatim_quote: this service generally costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season for the mobile platform, depending on the complexity and novelty of the recording system required

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu and MEMSAP customisation valued at $15,000 each for first year
evidence.verbatim_quote: Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each for their first year of deployment

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu subsequent deployment cost only $3,250
evidence.verbatim_quote: but only $3,250 for a subsequent deployment for Boncuklu

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC first year cost only $900, subsequent deployment $2,400
evidence.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900 (a subsequent deployment cost $2,400, after they identified some additional modifications)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Single context at Boncuklu may be resolved within less than 5 cm of deposit
evidence.verbatim_quote: [a single context in] Boncuklu may be resolved within <5 cm of deposit

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson required only three iterations of excavation module and two of survey module
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ultimately only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed in the field

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC module produced in approximately three and a half weeks from first contact to deployment
evidence.verbatim_quote: The total time that elapsed between first contact with FAIMS leadership and deployment of the finished PAZC module was approximately three and a half weeks

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn's record input time increased from 20 minutes to over an hour due to slowdown
evidence.verbatim_quote: A record which initially took 20 minutes to input took over an hour due to slow syncing and updating

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn achieved 95% labour saving: 1-1.5 days handling time with FAIMS vs 25-30 days without
evidence.verbatim_quote: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn's post-processing took 2-3 hours vs several hundred hours for paper entry of 300+ context records
evidence.verbatim_quote: post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn estimated savings of AU$5,000-10,000 per annum in paid RA time
evidence.verbatim_quote: This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson's survey team saved at least eight person-days of work with tablets
evidence.verbatim_quote: the tablets saved at least eight person-days of work

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson noted transcription error cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify
evidence.verbatim_quote: nor did they suffer from the inevitable transcription error that in this case cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS wifi provided 75-80% signal strength at 80m distance
evidence.verbatim_quote: the [wifi] provided excellent coverage (75–80% signal strength at 80m, the furthest excavation trench

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh's online server upload speeds averaged only 25 Kbps
evidence.verbatim_quote: our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh had to set up 100-meter network cable to nearby internet café
evidence.verbatim_quote: we set up a wireless access point in our dig house by running a 100-meter network cable from a nearby internet café and connecting it to a wireless router

evidence.evidence_text: One tablet screen cracked when item fell on it from trench edge
evidence.verbatim_quote: with the exception of 1 tablet screen—cracked when an item fell on it from the edge of the trench

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu, MEMSAP, PAZC all used single-context recording systems
evidence.verbatim_quote: Single context recording describes each deposit, cut and feature in detail

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS software is free and open source under GPLv.3 licence
evidence.verbatim_quote: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS uses GitHub for publishing and managing modules
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project uses GitHub, an online version control tool for collaborative software development, to publish and manage individual modules

evidence.evidence_text: Deluxe excavation module developed in 2013 served as foundation for three case studies
evidence.verbatim_quote: in 2013, the FAIMS team developed a 'deluxe excavation' module, which provided the foundation for the three deployments discussed here

evidence.evidence_text: FileMaker requires workarounds for offline multi-device data collection
evidence.verbatim_quote: they operate grudgingly in a network-degraded field environment, requiring work-arounds when asked to collect data simultaneously on multiple offline devices

evidence.evidence_text: Case study communications available via digital supplement
evidence.verbatim_quote: their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume

evidence.evidence_text: Four customisation methods available for do-it-yourself users
evidence.verbatim_quote: do-it-yourself users can customise the mobile application for their own work in four ways

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC translation from Boncuklu module required less than one week after requirements specified
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified

claims.claim_text: The FAIMS project is a university-based e-research initiative that developed national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative that was launched in 2012 to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data
claims.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data

claims.claim_text: Field deployments of the mobile platform informed ongoing development resulting in FAIMS 2.0
claims.verbatim_quote: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

claims.claim_text: Generalised software allows deep customisation, adapting to user approach rather than requiring users to adapt to the software
claims.verbatim_quote: Generalised software allows deep customisation, adapting to the user's approach and procedures rather than requiring than the user adapt to the software, while still being designed specifically for archaeology

claims.claim_text: Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring advantages of bespoke software within reach of typical projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring the advantages of bespoke software within reach of 'typical' projects

claims.claim_text: Co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and software development team that eases transitions from paper to digital fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team. This partnership can ease the transitions from paper to digital fieldwork, illuminate the advantages digital approaches offer, and ensure that software is fit-to-purpose

claims.claim_text: FAIMS sustainability plan involves iterative applications for research infrastructure funding primarily through ARC LIEF program
claims.verbatim_quote: The sustainability plan of the FAIMS project involves iterative applications for research infrastructure funding, primarily through the ARC LIEF program

claims.claim_text: FAIMS envisions service fees will constitute 25% of budget within five years but will remain largely dependent on infrastructure grants
claims.verbatim_quote: We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions

claims.claim_text: Users with time and expertise can implement FAIMS themselves through four progressively complex customisation methods
claims.verbatim_quote: Users with the time and expertise can implement FAIMS themselves, or they can purchase that service from the FAIMS team

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Most users have chosen to purchase customisation and support services from the FAIMS team
claims.verbatim_quote: Most users, however, have chosen to purchase customisation and support services from the FAIMS team

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Number of supported projects likely to double by end of 2017
claims.verbatim_quote: That number is likely to double by the end of 2017

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: FAIMS offers affordable deployment options including pre-configured servers and leasing arrangements
claims.verbatim_quote: Purchasing a pre-configured local server with all necessary hardware costs AUD $1,700–$3,500

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Complex novel recording systems require more expensive customisation than simpler adaptations
claims.verbatim_quote: depending on the complexity and novelty of the recording system required

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Subsequent deployments are less expensive because users only pay for changes and support
claims.verbatim_quote: Deployments of a module for subsequent seasons are usually less expensive because users only pay for changes and support

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Reusing existing modules demonstrates significant cost savings compared to developing new modules
claims.verbatim_quote: illustrating the savings that redeployment can offer

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Single-context recording method is appropriate for sites with fine layering and complex intercutting features
claims.verbatim_quote: excavation has necessarily been fine-grained, utilising a single context recording method better to understand the subtle interrelationships of the site's building sequences

claims.claim_text: Established projects with prior paper-based workflows can reduce iteration cycles during module development
claims.verbatim_quote: this was likely because all of the data categories and relationships had been worked out—in paper version—over the course of previous field seasons

claims.claim_text: Willingness to adapt existing modules enables rapid production of new deployments
claims.verbatim_quote: The speed of production was possible because of VanValkenburgh's pragmatism and willingness to adapt an existing module

claims.claim_text: Complex auto-generated context identifiers caused exponential performance degradation as databases grew
claims.verbatim_quote: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew (more precisely, as a square function of the number of records)

claims.claim_text: Encoding multiple variables in context identifiers compromises performance and costs development time
claims.verbatim_quote: The implementation of this five-variables-in-one-field feature was possible, but it reduced performance and cost significant development time, which could have been better spent on other features or on testing

claims.claim_text: Digital recording eliminates tedious post-excavation digitisation and associated transcription errors
claims.verbatim_quote: an entire season's data could be retrieved immediately, without tedious digitisation and the errors it inevitably introduces

claims.claim_text: Time savings at end of project are substantial and can recoup customisation costs
claims.verbatim_quote: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant

claims.claim_text: Digital data processing requires significantly less time than manual paper entry for large datasets
claims.verbatim_quote: post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records

claims.claim_text: Tablets present huge advantage for survey data in terms of automatic integration of disparate data types
claims.verbatim_quote: it became very clear to the survey team that the tablets presented a huge advantage

claims.claim_text: Digital data collection reduces transcription errors that cost significant time to investigate and rectify
claims.verbatim_quote: nor did they suffer from the inevitable transcription error that in this case cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify

claims.claim_text: FAIMS-in-a-box hardware proved reliable under challenging field conditions including dust and unreliable electricity
claims.verbatim_quote: the equipment—FAIMS-in-a-box—worked very well and with the exception of 1 tablet screen—cracked when an item fell on it from the edge of the trench—came through the season in great condition. This was in spite of very dusty conditions and a somewhat unreliable electricity supply

claims.claim_text: Online servers are unreliable in remote fieldwork settings with poor internet connectivity
claims.verbatim_quote: our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight

claims.claim_text: Recording protocols should contain checks and constraints while allowing freehand observations for unexpected findings
claims.verbatim_quote: it was desirable that the recording protocols contain as many checks and constraints as possible, but also that there was ample opportunity to freehand any observations that may not fit into one of the pre-designated categories

claims.claim_text: Free and open source licensing enables sharing and adaptation of FAIMS software and modules
claims.verbatim_quote: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: GitHub enables version control, forking, and pulling improvements back into original modules
claims.verbatim_quote: Using GitHub not only made the definition documents for all four modules (the original plus the three adaptations) publicly available, but it also allowed for the most useful changes to each of the derivative modules to be incorporated ('pulled') back into the original 'deluxe excavation' module

claims.claim_text: Commercial database software requires workarounds for field conditions because it was not designed for degraded network environments
claims.verbatim_quote: FileMaker was designed for everyone; FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage the high-friction environment of fieldwork

claims.claim_text: Complete unedited communications with project directors are available as supplementary material for transparency
claims.verbatim_quote: their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume

claims.claim_text: Converting paper to digital workflows requires making implicit knowledge embedded in paper forms explicit
claims.verbatim_quote: It requires making the implicit knowledge embedded in paper forms explicit. Digital forms are also more formalised and restrictive than paper forms

claims.claim_text: Digital conversion often instigates thorough review and revision of existing recording procedures
claims.verbatim_quote: The conversion from fuzzy paper forms to sharp digital recording often instigates a thorough review and revision of existing recording procedures and workflows

claims.claim_text: Testing must be thorough, with multiple participants, and in authentic field situations
claims.verbatim_quote: All project directors tested their modules ahead of fieldwork, but eventually they all regretted not doing so more thoroughly, with more participants, and in more authentic situations

claims.claim_text: Archaeologists tend to prioritise feature development at expense of testing
claims.verbatim_quote: In the FAIMS experience, archaeologists tended to prioritise the development of new features at the expense of testing

claims.claim_text: Hardware-specific bugs require testing on each actual device to be used in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: Software that worked during internal testing by the FAIMS team (or even by archaeologists prior to fieldwork) did not always work on different tablets, even if they were made by the same manufacturer

claims.claim_text: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field, especially purpose-built research software
claims.verbatim_quote: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field, especially software that is purpose-built for the research community

claims.claim_text: Digital recording improved both richness and integrity of field data across case studies
claims.verbatim_quote: our final review of data collected by the PAZC in 2014 suggests that using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data

claims.claim_text: Immediate availability of digital data enables timely discovery of errors that would otherwise go undetected until much later
claims.verbatim_quote: Even when digital data creation does not prevent errors, it exposes them

claims.claim_text: Legacy paper-based systems should be questioned when going digital rather than faithfully replicated
claims.verbatim_quote: It is worthwhile to step back and consider the purpose behind legacy recording approaches, and weigh the problems and benefits of replicating them

claims.claim_text: Local dedicated hardware servers are more expensive but offer greater reliability and faster synchronisation than online servers
claims.verbatim_quote: Local, dedicated hardware servers are more expensive than online servers, and they require that users test and maintain them, but they are faster and more robust than online servers

claims.claim_text: Digital recording enables collection of more data without increasing field season duration
claims.verbatim_quote: Because FAIMS enabled data to be collected and processed so efficiently, we were able to collect more data, and this expanded the interpretations we could make from a field season of the same duration

claims.claim_text: Digital data model building compels archaeologists to review their recording practices more generally
claims.verbatim_quote: The process of building data models and accommodating the precision of digital systems also compels archaeologists to review their recording practices more generally

claims.claim_text: Digital recording has not immediately changed substantive research goals but may enable more rigorous analysis later
claims.verbatim_quote: so far conversion [to digital recording] has not changed our substantive research goals

claims.claim_text: Full benefits of digital recording may not be realised until datasets are published and researchers start reusing and combining them
claims.verbatim_quote: Only after digital datasets are published and researchers start reusing and combining them will the full potential and impact of digital methods be realised

claims.claim_text: FAIMS strikes good balance between redeployability of general-purpose software and domain-specific capability of bespoke applications
claims.verbatim_quote: The authors of this paper believe that FAIMS strikes a good balance between the re-deployability of general-purpose database software and the domain- and project-specific capability of bespoke applications

claims.claim_text: Software co-development involving genuine partnership between archaeologists and technologists yields systems that are effective and fit-to-purpose
claims.verbatim_quote: Software co-development in a generalised framework like FAIMS, involving a genuine partnership between archaeologists and technologists, is a difficult but productive process that can yield systems that are effective and fit-to-purpose

claims.claim_text: Developing software that is fit-for-purpose is hard but the benefits are worth it
claims.verbatim_quote: Developing software that is fit-for-purpose is hard, but the benefits of doing it right are worth it

claims.claim_text: Bespoke applications are expensive to build and difficult to sustain for most archaeological projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Bespoke applications, while capable of producing good outcomes, are expensive to build and difficult to sustain

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Archaeological fieldwork has unique requirements that justify purpose-built software rather than adaptation of general-purpose commercial tools
trigger_text: FileMaker was designed for everyone; FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage the high-friction environment of fieldwork
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The comparison between FileMaker and FAIMS assumes that archaeological fieldwork conditions are sufficiently unusual to warrant specialised software development, without explicitly arguing why archaeology is different from other mobile data collection domains

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Open-source development models are inherently more sustainable and beneficial for academic research software than proprietary models
trigger_text: This infrastructure grant income is supplemented by fees charged for customisation, field support, server hosting, and other services (a typical open-source business model
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper assumes the open-source model is appropriate for research infrastructure without explicitly comparing sustainability outcomes with proprietary alternatives or discussing potential drawbacks

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The cost savings from eliminating post-excavation digitisation outweigh the upfront investment in digital infrastructure
trigger_text: customisation and support costs of this magnitude can be largely recouped from later savings in data digitisation and reconciliation

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper provides cost figures for customisation but assumes without comprehensive accounting that time savings post-fieldwork reliably offset these costs across different project types and scales

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Professional software engineering teams produce higher quality software than academic developers working in isolation
trigger_text: This funding allows the FAIMS project to employ a professional software engineering team (as well as student programmers) to ensure that our software meets high standards and avoids some of the shortcomings often associated with academic software
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper assumes professional development produces better outcomes than typical academic software without providing comparative evidence or acknowledging cases where academic software has succeeded

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Three case studies are sufficient to derive generalisable lessons about co-development of archaeological software
trigger_text: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper draws broad conclusions about co-development from three projects that all used the same base platform and involved similar relationship with the development team, without acknowledging potential selection bias or limited generalisability

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Data born digital is inherently superior to data digitised from paper records
trigger_text: an entire season's data could be retrieved immediately, without tedious digitisation and the errors it inevitably introduces
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper assumes digital-born data is always preferable without discussing potential drawbacks such as reduced flexibility for unusual observations or the archaeological tradition of interpretive note-taking

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The learning curve and upfront time investment for digital recording is acceptable given long-term benefits
trigger_text: Learning the capabilities of FAIMS software and engaging in the scoping and testing required by co-development all took more time before fieldwork than producing paper forms would have
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper acknowledges upfront costs but assumes projects have sufficient resources and time flexibility to absorb this investment, without addressing projects with limited pre-fieldwork time or resources

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Quantitative time-saving metrics adequately capture the value proposition of digital recording systems
trigger_text: saved at least eight person-days of work
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper emphasises quantified time savings as the primary metric of success, implicitly assuming this captures the full value of digital approaches without considering qualitative changes to research practice or data richness

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The FAIMS team's perspective on co-development challenges is objective and representative
trigger_text: In this paper, three project directors who co-developed and deployed a FAIMS recording system in collaboration with the FAIMS team report their experiences
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Authors include FAIMS team members who have a stake in positive evaluation of the platform; the paper does not address potential conflicts of interest in reporting

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Testing in authentic field conditions is both possible and practical for archaeological projects
trigger_text: Test all hardware and software again under authentic conditions
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper recommends authentic testing without addressing practical barriers such as the cost of pre-fieldwork field trips, access to remote sites before the project begins, or the difficulty of simulating actual excavation conditions

research_designs.design_text: Multi-case study design using three archaeological field projects to evaluate cooperative deployment of generalised software
research_designs.verbatim_quote: In this paper, three project directors who co-developed and deployed a FAIMS recording system in collaboration with the FAIMS team report their experiences
research_designs.design_rationale: Multiple case studies allow identification of common themes across different archaeological contexts (Turkey, Malawi, Peru)

research_designs.design_text: Reflective practitioner evaluation where software developers and archaeologist users collaboratively report on deployment experiences
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Having first-hand experience of co-development, they reflect on the challenges and benefits of working with the FAIMS project team
research_designs.design_rationale: First-hand practitioner reflection provides insight into practical challenges of software co-development

research_designs.design_text: Thematic analysis design synthesising observations across three case studies into common themes
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects
research_designs.design_rationale: Thematic synthesis enables identification of generalisable lessons from diverse project contexts

research_designs.design_text: Cost-benefit analysis comparing upfront software development investment against post-fieldwork time savings
trigger_text: customisation and support costs of this magnitude can be largely recouped from later savings in data digitisation and reconciliation

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper structures quantitative evidence around comparing investment costs to time/money savings, suggesting an implicit cost-benefit analytical framework
research_designs.design_rationale: Cost-benefit framing helps justify investment in digital infrastructure

research_designs.design_text: Software development process documentation through longitudinal tracking of module creation and deployment
research_designs.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork
research_designs.design_rationale: Longitudinal documentation captures evolving experiences and challenges through the deployment process

methods.method_text: Case study selection based on diversity of archaeological contexts and use of same base platform
methods.verbatim_quote: The three FAIMS implementation case studies presented here include: (1) a Neolithic tell excavation in central Turkey, (2) a Middle Stone Age excavation and surface survey in Malawi, and (3) a late Prehispanic/early Colonial excavation in coastal Peru

methods.method_text: Mixed qualitative data collection using questionnaires and communication logs
methods.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork

methods.method_text: Thematic content analysis to identify common patterns across case study experiences
trigger_text: Their observations can be woven into three themes
methods.inference_reasoning: The organisation of findings into three themes implies a thematic analysis approach, though the specific coding/analysis procedure is not described

methods.method_text: Direct quotation of participant perspectives to present first-hand experiences
methods.verbatim_quote: These sources provide the quotations below

methods.method_text: Quantitative comparison of time/cost metrics before and after digital recording adoption
methods.verbatim_quote: post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records

methods.method_text: Longitudinal tracking of project communications throughout deployment lifecycle
methods.verbatim_quote: exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork

methods.method_text: Software deployment and customisation process documentation
methods.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

methods.method_text: Module development using iterative scoping, coding, and quality assurance cycle
methods.verbatim_quote: treat each deployment as an authentic, miniature software development project that requires proper 'scoping' (requirements gathering, software design, and development planning), coding, and 'quality assurance' (testing at each step of development)

protocols.protocol_text: Selection of three case study projects representing different geographical and archaeological contexts
protocols.verbatim_quote: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences

protocols.protocol_text: Administration of post-project questionnaires to project directors
protocols.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires

protocols.protocol_text: Collection and archiving of email and chat communications between FAIMS team and project directors
protocols.verbatim_quote: exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork

protocols.protocol_text: Selection and presentation of direct quotations from project director communications
protocols.verbatim_quote: These sources provide the quotations below

protocols.protocol_text: Calculation of time savings by comparing paper-based versus digital data processing hours
trigger_text: 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours
1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days
protocols.inference_reasoning: Specific time comparisons indicate a calculation protocol was used, though the exact methodology for tracking and comparing hours is not detailed

protocols.protocol_text: Tracking of deployment statistics including project counts and field support instances
trigger_text: we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

protocols.inference_reasoning: Precise deployment statistics indicate systematic tracking, though the specific tracking mechanism is not described

protocols.protocol_text: Requirements gathering through meetings and discussions with project personnel
protocols.verbatim_quote: Several hours were spent in discussions with all senior project personnel to ensure that all data types they wanted recorded were represented in the modules

protocols.protocol_text: Iterative module development with multiple prototype versions
protocols.verbatim_quote: only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed

protocols.protocol_text: Pre-fieldwork module testing to ensure technical functionality
protocols.verbatim_quote: Testing the module prior to fieldwork ensured it was technically functional, and allowed for communication of changes that would be hard done remotely

protocols.protocol_text: Module customisation using XML definition documents and BeanShell scripting
protocols.verbatim_quote: Modify an existing module, or create a new one, by editing the definition documents directly, which requires proficiency with XML and BeanShell (a scripting language)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

protocols.protocol_text: Module forking and adaptation using GitHub version control
protocols.verbatim_quote: This module was duplicated ('forked') and modified to meet the needs of each project

protocols.protocol_text: Server deployment options: local hardware, virtual machine, or cloud server
protocols.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS server can take different forms. A virtualised instance of the server can run online (e.g., in the Australian NeCTAR Research Cloud) or on client laptops, or clients can commission a customised and preconfigured hardware package

protocols.protocol_text: Data export from FAIMS to CSV format for integration with legacy databases
protocols.verbatim_quote: He received his comma separated value (CSV; a standard spreadsheet-type format) data files and created an Access database from them

protocols.protocol_text: Translation of modules into other languages by editing definition documents
protocols.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents

funding.funder: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program
Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF)

repositories.name: Digital supplement to volume
repositories.content: Complete unedited communications with FAIMS project, customised modules

fair_assessment.rationale: Software is findable via GitHub and Google Play but paper lacks DOI. Code is accessible under GPLv.3 licence with good documentation. Modules are interoperable (XML-based) but require FAIMS platform. Supplementary materials with case study data and modules support reusability. No ORCIDs provided. Total: 22/40

known_limitations: Paper lacks DOI - book chapter format
No formal ethics or conflicts of interest statements
Thematic analysis coding procedure not described in detail
extraction_notes.extraction_approach: Liberal extraction with 40-50% over-extraction targeting methodological paper profile. Equal attention to all sections with particular focus on co-development themes.

pass_summary.pass_0: Metadata extracted: 6 authors, book chapter in edited volume
pass_summary.pass_1: Evidence extracted: 35 items covering quantitative costs, time savings, deployment statistics
pass_summary.pass_2: Claims extracted: 50 items covering methodological arguments, interpretations, and empirical findings
pass_summary.pass_3: Implicit arguments extracted: 10 items identifying unstated assumptions and bridging claims
pass_summary.pass_4: Research designs extracted: 5 designs covering case study, thematic, and cost-benefit approaches
pass_summary.pass_5: Methods extracted: 8 methods covering sampling, data collection, and analysis
pass_summary.pass_6: Protocols extracted: 14 protocols covering data collection, development, and deployment procedures
pass_summary.pass_7: Infrastructure extracted: Funding (3 grants), code availability (GitHub, GPLv.3), supplementary materials (5 items)
